author: chfast
content: We didn't deploy EEST on the eof-devnet-0, did we?

author: marioevz
content: I don't think so, I think <@403707149043105803> was running `uv run execute` in a local devnet but not the actual devnet-0, but please correct me if I'm wrong

author: _shemnon
content: the only success I was having with run execute was deploying the contracts.  There were TX issues relating to upfront cost that kept the executions from happening.  But all the initcode was fine.

author: marioevz
content: For the Devnet-0 release from EEST of EOF, I'd like to merge Pawel's PR before tagging, I'm currently reviewing üëç

author: chfast
content: There are still some gaps in the test coverage we know about

author: pdobacz
content:
On that topic: I just checked `eofwrap` locally with `master` evmone - seems to be working fine. It seems 7623 has taken down some more tests from the 1559 bunch (intrinsic gas changes), but we can live without these. All the legacy opcodes we intended to test in EOF are still covered üëå .

Since `eofwrap` has never been disabled for EOF test releases, it doesn't need to be reenabled. The next EOF release should include it (which I'll test on the ipsilon fork in a second, just to be sure)

author: racytech
content: I am a bit confused with the error returned from `eof_tests/eof_create/subcontainer_validation/container_both_kinds_same_sub`. from the description `Test subcontainer conflicts (both EOFCREATE and RETURNCONTRACT Reference)`. this test expects `INCOMPATIBLE_CONTAINER_KIND` error, but evmone seems to return `AMBIGUOUS_CONTAINER_KIND` when both instructions refer to the same subcontainer. Not much of a difference,  but still would be good to know what kind of error it should return

author: _shemnon
content: That it fails is what is important.  The specific failure is advisory.  Perhaps we should update the test.

author: racytech
content: Just want to make sure I am hitting the right error, when it expects me to do so

author: _shemnon
content: The issue we have is that the parsers sometimes go about valiation in different orders, so when there are multiple failures we cannot say "must fail with this code".  However, this appears to be the case of a client updating their error message and the test harness not being updated to reflect the new name is the same failure category as the old one.

author: _shemnon
content: Just focus on pass/fail, the error codes give you signal as to why it should be failing, in the event the validator claims it passes.
